words.title: Insert mode
words.meaning:
To insert text before the cursor
It is also used to enter Insert Mode

words.title: Command mode
words.usage_more: Just press the escape key on the key

words.title: Cutting
words.meaning: In normal mode, d is the key for deleting (cutting) text. Here are some other helpful deleting commands:
words.usage:
# dd - Delete (cut) the current line, including the newline character.
# 3dd - Delete (cut) three lines, starting from the line where the cursor is positioned.
# d$ - Delete (cut) everything from the cursor to the end of the line.
words.usage_more: The movement commands that apply for yanking are also valid for deleting. For example dw, deletes to the start of the next word, and d^ deletes everything from the cursor to the start of the line.

words.usage:
# dd - Delete (cut) the current line, including the newline character.

words.usage_more: The movement commands that apply for yanking are also valid for deleting. For example dw, deletes to the start of the next word, and d^ deletes everything from the cursor to the start of the line.

words.title: Paste
words.meaning: To paste the lines in the buffer into the text after the current line.

words.title: Undo
words.meaning: To undo what you just did.

words.title: Copy
words.meaning: To copy text, place the cursor in the desired location and press the y key followed by the movement command. Below are some helpful yanking commands:
words.usage:
yy - Yank (copy) the current line, including the newline character.
# 3yy - Yank (copy) three lines, starting from the line where the cursor is positioned.
# y$ - Yank (copy) everything from the cursor to the end of the line.
# y^ - Yank (copy) everything from the cursor to the start of the line.
# yw - Yank (copy) to the start of the next word.
# yiw – Yank (copy) the current word.
# y% - Yank (copy) to the matching character. By default supported pairs are (), {}, and []. Useful to copy text between matching brackets.

words.title: Copy
words.meaning: To copy text, place the cursor in the desired location and press the y key followed by the movement command. Below are some helpful yanking commands:
words.usage:
yy - Yank (copy) the current line, including the newline character.
# 3yy - Yank (copy) three lines, starting from the line where the cursor is positioned.
# y$ - Yank (copy) everything from the cursor to the end of the line.
# y^ - Yank (copy) everything from the cursor to the start of the line.
# yw - Yank (copy) to the start of the next word.
# yiw – Yank (copy) the current word.
# y% - Yank (copy) to the matching character. By default supported pairs are (), {}, and []. Useful to copy text between matching brackets.

words.title: Quit/Exiting/Leaving
words.usage:
# :x - quit vi, writing out modified file to file named in original invocation.
# :q - quit vi, writing out modified file to file named in original invocation.
# :q - quit(exit) vi
# :q! - quit vi even though latest changes have not been saved for this vi call

words.title: Move cursor to the start of the line
words.meaning: To move the cursor to the start of the current line.

words.title: Move cursor to the end of the line
words.meaning: To move the cursor to the end of the current line.
